fields.note: We base your benefit estimate on current formulas from the Social Security Administration. Your answers are anonymous. Because we do not access or use your Social Security earnings record, these are rough estimates.
fields.instructions: Enter your information below to see your estimated benefits.
fields.title: Explore how your claiming age affects your Social Security retirement benefits

fields.instructions: Picture your life in retirement to receive claiming tips.
fields.title: Learn tips specific to your situation

fields.note: (This will not affect your Social Security account or begin an application.)
fields.instructions: Select the age you plan to claim your Social Security retirement benefits.
fields.title: Learn your next steps

fields.instructions: Create a my Social Security account to review your expected benefits based on your actual Social Security record. You will also find additional information about your eligibility and other benefits including disability and survivor benefits.
fields.title: final_step_1

fields.instructions: Your retirement income outside of Social Security will help you cover your expenses. You can increase your contributions to your retirement savings plans, or open and contribute to an IRA plan.
fields.title: final_step_2_under

fields.instructions: If your income, employment, or marital status changes, you may need to reconsider your claiming age. Visit us again!
fields.title: final_step_3

fields.instructions: Was this page helpful in thinking about your claiming age decision?
fields.title: final_step_4

fields.instructions: While you wait to claim your benefits, you can continue growing your savings by making catchup contributions to your existing accounts. You may also be able to open and contribute to an IRA.
fields.title: final_step_2_equal

fields.instructions: While you let your benefits continue to grow, you can keep working if you want. You can also stop working and use a portion of your savings to cover your needs. Learn the rules about withdrawing money from your retirement accounts.
fields.title: final_step_2_over

fields.aside: Claiming at your full retirement age locks in your full monthly benefit.
Claiming at the earliest year locks in a monthly benefit about 30% below your full retirement amount.
Claiming four years early locks in a benefit about 25% below your full amount.
Claiming three years early locks in a benefit about 20% below your full amount.
Claiming two years early locks in a benefit about 13% below your full amount.
Claiming a year early locks in a benefit about 6.7% below your full amount.
Waiting a year to claim boosts your monthly benefit by about 8%.
Waiting two years to claim boosts your monthly benefit by about 16%.
Waiting until 70 gets you the maximum monthly benefit.

fields.title: Before You Claim
fields.intro: The age you claim Social Security affects your lifetime income. We’ll help you think through this decision.

fields.text: Maximum retirement age: Always 70. This is the age at which you will get the maximum possible benefit. You should not claim your benefit after this age.
fields.title: max

fields.text: Early retirement: Any time before your full retirement age. If you claim your benefits before your full retirement age, they will be permanently reduced. The earliest age you can claim your retirement benefit is 62.
fields.title: early

fields.text: Social Security retirement benefits are not designed to be your sole source of retirement income, but waiting even one month will increase your benefits.
fields.title: sole_source

fields.text: We calculate benefit estimates based on the Social Security Administration's Quick Calculator. The SSA uses the date of birth and current income values to build an average lifetime earnings history and calculate benefits. The benefit estimates we provide are only approximations, and are intended solely as a way to show how different claiming dates can affect monthly benefits. Social Security will calculate more accurate benefits estimates based on your actual lifetime earnings if you go to Social Security's sign-up page and create an account.
fields.title: calculations

fields.text: Full retirement age varies between 66 and 67 depending on your date of birth. This is the age at which you will receive your full benefit with no reductions.
fields.title: fra

fields.text: Enter your total work income before taxes and other deductions. If your work income is 0 (zero) because you are now retired or unemployed, enter the income for the last year in which you worked.
fields.title: salary

fields.text: On average, a woman reaching age 65 today will live to age 87, and a man will live to age 84.
fields.title: lifetime

fields.text: If you and your spouse are full retirement age, you can apply for benefits but have the payments suspended. This allows your spouse to file for spousal benefits without affecting your personal benefits. For details, see Social Security's guide.
fields.title: file_and_suspend

fields.text: If both spouses are full retirement age, you can apply for spousal benefits if you haven't filed before and if your spouse has already filed (regardless of your spouse's suspension status). For details, see Social Security's guide.
fields.title: restricted_application

fields.text: Our tool shows your estimated benefit for nine specific claiming points. However, you can claim at any point between age 62 and 70, and your benefit amount will depend on the specific month that you claim.
fields.title: estimated_benefits

fields.text: Once you reach your full retirement benefits claiming age, you can work and earn as much as you want and your benefits will not be reduced. If you claim before this age and continue to work, your benefits could be temporarily reduced if you earn over a certain limit, but any reductions you receive will be credited back to you once you reach full retirement age.
fields.title: working_longer

fields.text: A type of retirement savings account offered by employers to help their employees save for retirement.
fields.title: 401k

fields.text: Your Social Security benefits could be reduced if you receive federal, state, or local government pensions that are based on work where you did not pay Social Security taxes.
fields.title: pensions

fields.text: IRAs are types of retirement savings plans with special tax incentives. In these plans, your savings equal the contributions that you make to the account plus the gains or losses of your investments.
fields.title: iras

fields.text: Catch-up contributions are additional contributions that individuals who are age 50 or older can make to their 401(k) or IRA accounts to help them boost their savings as they approach retirement.
fields.title: catchup_contributions

fields.text: If you claim before full retirement age and continue to work, your benefits could be temporarily reduced if you earn over a certain amount. Any reductions you receive will be credited back to you once you reach full retirement age.
fields.title: claim_early_and_work

fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: Your claiming age matters for your own retirement benefits and your survivor's benefits.
fields.title: Marriage
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: Claiming at your full retirement age or later permanently increases your benefit.
fields.answer_yes_a: Your decision of when to claim your Social Security could affect the benefits  your spouse will receive after you die. Surviving spouses can keep either their own benefit or choose to keep their spouse's benefit, whichever is higher. If you are married, and are the higher earner in the household, claiming at your full benefit age will ensure your spouse will receive the higher benefit. Talk to your spouse about your claiming options so you can make this important decision together.
fields.question: Are you married?
fields.answer_unsure_a: You may qualify for a survivor benefit if your deceased spouse qualified for Social Security. You can wait until age 70 to claim your survivor benefit and get the maximum amount possible, or you can claim a reduced survivor benefit as early as age 60. You may also qualify for a retirement benefit based on your own earnings record, but you will only receive one benefit at a time. If you expect your own retirement benefit to be higher than the survivor benefit, you may want to consider claiming the survivor benefit first. That way, you can start receiving some money from Social Security as your own retirement benefit continues to grow.
fields.answer_yes_a_subhed: You can protect the financial security of your surviving spouse.
fields.answer_no_a: If you claim at your full Social Security benefit age or later, you will avoid a reduction in your monthly benefit. In addition, if you choose to wait to claim past your full benefit age until age 70, you can get an increase for every month that you wait. If you are divorced, your former spouse's claiming decision will not affect your benefit, so it should not affect your decision of when to claim.

fields.answer_no_b_subhed: You can maximize your benefits even if you work fewer hours or stop working.
fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: Consider working in your 60s for an extra boost to your income and savings.
fields.answer_yes_b_subhed: Working in your 60s will help you maximize your income and savings.
fields.title: Sixties
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: You can maximize your benefits even if you work fewer hours or stop working.
fields.question: Do you plan to continue working in your 60s?
fields.answer_unsure_b_subhed: Consider working extra years in your 60s for an extra boost to your income and savings
fields.answer_yes_a_subhed: Working in your 60s will help you maximize your income and savings.

fields.answer_no_b_subhed: Many people find retirement is more expensive than expected.
fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: You can protect your lifestyle by planning ahead.
fields.title: Expenses
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: Many people find retirement is more expensive than expected.
fields.answer_yes_b: If you're planning an active retirement or carry a mortgage or other debt, your first few years in retirement may be more expensive than you expect. Some regular expenses like your out-of-pocket health care costs will likely increase as you get older. You can protect your retirement lifestyle by reducing your largest expenses. You can also increase your regular income by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim earlier, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.

fields.question: Will your expenses decrease after you retire?
fields.answer_unsure_b: Future expenses are difficult to predict. Some regular expenses like out-of-pocket health care costs will likely increase as you get older. You can protect your retirement lifestyle by reducing your largest expenses. Consider downsizing or paying off your mortgage before you retire. You can also increase your regular income by claiming at your full Social Security benefit age or later. If you claim earlier, your monthly benefit could be reduced by as much as 30 percent.

fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: There are many ways to plan for a secure retirement outside of Social Security.

fields.title: Income
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: It's a perfect time to start saving.
fields.question: Do you expect to have additional sources of retirement income beyond Social Security?
fields.answer_unsure_b_subhed: It's never too late to start saving!
fields.answer_yes_a_subhed: Continue saving in the coming years.

fields.answer_unsure_a_subhed: There's a good chance that you'll live into your 80s and beyond.
fields.title: Long life
fields.answer_no_a_subhed: Claiming at your full benefit age could still make sense for you.
fields.answer_yes_a: Because Social Security provides guaranteed income for life, it's especially valuable to you when you reach age 80 and beyond. Claiming benefits at your full Social Security benefit age or later could be a good way to secure your monthly income during your later years.  Your benefit increases the longer you wait to claim, up to age 70, and is adjusted annually with the cost of living. If you live into your 80s but claim at age 62 instead of your full retirement age or later, your total lifetime benefits will be lower by thousands of dollars.
fields.question: Do you expect to live a long life?
fields.answer_unsure_a: We understand it's difficult to make predictions. You may want to plan for the possibility that you (or your spouse) may live a long life. On average, a woman reaching age 65 today will live to age 87, and a man will live to age 84. Claiming benefits at your full Social Security benefit age or later could be a good way to secure your monthly income during your later years. Your monthly benefit increases the longer you wait to claim, up to age 70, and is adjusted annually with the cost of living. If you live into your 80s but claim at age 62 instead of your full retirement age or later, your total lifetime benefits will be lower by thousands of dollars.
fields.answer_yes_a_subhed: Protect yourself from outliving your money.
fields.answer_no_a: We understand it's difficult to make predictions. You may want to plan for the possibility that you (or your spouse) may live a long life. On average, a woman reaching age 65 today will live to age 87, and a man will live to age 84. Waiting to claim as long as you can could still make sense for you if you are married, are the higher earner in the household, and want your surviving spouse to keep the highest monthly benefit after you die. Remember, you can claim at any point between age 62 and 70. Each additional month that you wait to claim gives you a permanent increase in your monthly benefit which becomes more valuable as you age.
